9d1c30a9-7aa4-4230-b130-dc65467145a8.summary: Can moral decisions be justified without universal acceptance?
9d1c30a9-7aa4-4230-b130-dc65467145a8.content: {Gauguin may not be able to justify himself to others, as those who suffer from his decision may have justified grounds of reproach.}, {The idea that moral justifications should silence all complaints is unrealistically strong, as seen in political cases where moral costs are acknowledged.}, {The fact that these agents' justifications would not silence all complaints does not necessarily mean they are not moral justifications, but it raises questions about the nature of moral justification.}

b49b37d5-cf6c-4641-ae59-e045a526b4cd.content: {Moral value is immune to luck}, {Moral value is supreme and holds a special dignity}, {The capacity for moral agency is present in all rational agents}, {Moral judgments are free from external contingency}

755f714b-cfec-434d-87de-7dc67283d395.content: {Happiness is reflective tranquillity}, {Tranquillity is the product of self-sufficiency}, {What is not in the domain of the self is subject to luck}

d64f828e-0001-458e-97d8-7a2e773ae759.summary: Intrinsic and Extrinsic Luck in Moral Justification
d64f828e-0001-458e-97d8-7a2e773ae759.content: {Intrinsic luck affects the success of a project}, {Extrinsic luck does not discredit the project}, {Success justifies the decision retrospectively}

3e10d94b-28f1-4219-a7c5-57af6ee3ddec.summary: Does agent-regret reveal a flaw in moral justification?
3e10d94b-28f1-4219-a7c5-57af6ee3ddec.content: {Agent-regret involves a wish that one had acted otherwise, which is distinct from spectator's regret and indicates a personal connection to one's actions.}, {The presence of agent-regret in cases of involuntary agency suggests that moral justification cannot be entirely separated from the outcomes of one's actions.}, {The existence of agent-regret challenges the idea that moral justification can be purely rational and independent of the consequences of one's actions.}

5570520e-2276-4f3b-9b34-d0a635bcc101.content: {Moral value is immune to luck}, {Moral value is unconditioned by external factors}, {Moral value is accessible to all rational agents}, {Moral value possesses supreme dignity and importance}

8e2fb176-1493-434b-87fe-99513b88277d.content: {Rational justification is determined retrospectively by success}, {Intrinsic success justifies the decision}, {Extrinsic failure does not discredit the project}, {The agent's sense of significance is conditioned by the project's outcome}

6616f7c8-c541-4bb7-82b3-e959116093a2.content: {Constitutive luck affects one's capacity for moral agency}, {The capacity for moral agency is present in all rational agents}, {Moral agency is not dependent on external contingencies}, {Moral life is a career open to all rational beings}

97abc85c-b7bb-4b9b-a95f-178c98b877bf.summary: Is the concept of morality undermined by luck?
97abc85c-b7bb-4b9b-a95f-178c98b877bf.content: {Skepticism about the freedom of morality from luck cannot leave the concept of morality where it was, as it challenges the image of a moral order that transcends luck.}, {The involvement of morality with luck suggests that the concept of morality may be less important than it is usually taken to be.}, {The recognition of moral luck forces us to question the motive of establishing a dimension of decision and assessment that hopes to transcend luck.}
